revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2000 |Team=Florida State Seminoles |Image= FSU text logo.svg |ImageSize=125px |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference=ACC |CoachRank=3 |APRank=3 |Record=11-2 |ConfRecord=8-0 |HeadCoach=[[Bobby Bowden]] |OffCoach=[[Mark Richt]] |DefCoach=[[Mickey Andrews]] |OScheme=Pro Style |DScheme=[[4â3 defense|4-3]] Multiple |StadiumArena=[[Bobby Bowden Field at Doak Campbell Stadium|Doak Campbell Stadium]] |Champion=ACC Champions |BowlTourney=[[2001 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult= L 13-2 vs. [[2000 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] }} {{2000 ACC football standings}} The '''2000 Florida State Seminoles football team''' was the champion of the Atlantic Coast Conference. The team finished with a 11-2 record, and lost in the 2001 BCS National Title Game to the Oklahoma Sooners. They reached the Title game despite finishing 3rd in both the Coaches and AP polls.
==Regular season== As a senior in 2000, Chris Weinke led the nation in passing with 4,167 yards and won the [[Heisman Trophy]], awarded to college football's best player, as well as the [[Davey O'Brien Award]] and the [[Johnny Unitas Award]]. He also led the Seminoles to the [[2001 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] for their third title game in as many years, where they lost 13–2 to the [[2000 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma Sooners]]. At the age of 28, Weinke was the oldest player in history to win the Heisman Trophy. He finished his Florida State career with a 32–3 record and held numerous FSU records including most passing yards in a career and most career touchdown passes.
